title: Will Toyota sell or lease more than 750 Mirai in the US in 2016?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to LeftLane.com Toyota has already reached this goal for 2016
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
for those that want to keep track of Kumamoto Japan earthquakes.  The Motomachi Plant was shut down after a 4.5 earthquake.     http://earthquaketrack.com/p/japan/kumamoto/recent
709 sold so far, 40 per month for 3 months remaining. Remaining uncertainty is due to the question of how and why the peak August sales came about, and whether that might be revoked in some way.

Sold YTD 710, monthly increasing sales record. Will make 40 a month for oct to dec.
So they will make in my view the 750.
Risk a manufacturing problem, I am not aware of. E.g. Batteries, or not enough components
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
An Earthquake in Japan could torpedo the 750.
Barring something freakish, it is almost a done deal already.
40 cars to go. Should be no problem.

2016 YTD 710
http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html 750 target is likely to be met by next month - 2 months ahead of schedule.
710 ytd, which leaves only 40 needed for last 3 months. The drop in leasing costs seems to have really made the difference, especially as there as been no real change in the infrastructure.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Toyota Mirai lease price drops to $349/month
http://www.autoblog.com/2016/09/21/toyota-mirai-lease-rate-dropped-349-month/ Having already sold 641 vehicles this year, 109 in last 3 months is very achievable.

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/336048
This should probably be enough to push it over the line and signals that supply is not an issue.

Not sure if someone else has already explained the jump in August but it looks like it was due to lower leasing costs and the main buyers were Toyota employees (http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1106296_price-cut-and-monthly-sales-spike-for-toyota-mirai-fuel-cell-sedan). This would suggest some cannabilisation of future sales, so my forecast may be too high, but with only 28 a month needed for rest of year, will drop it down to 96%, and await what numbers we get in September.
Upping to 92% to keep pace with consensus.
(no change) Any thoughts about possible effects related to the overall shipping problems?
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

To update those who haven't checked in on this question in a while, here's what happened. The August sales were 371 [A1]. That's 1.4x the previous months combined. Cumulative sales are 641, meaning an average of 27.25 sales/month will get this to 750. I'm not sure what to make of this. We already knew that these sales were production-dependent (long waiting lists indicate demand is there). So my theory is either 1. They withheld inventory, perhaps due to infrastructure concerns 2. They were able to significantly increase production above the last-reported 10/day If it's option 1 this question might be a nail-biter. Leaving a little hedge for that. [A1] http://left-lane.com/us-car-sales-data/toyota/toyota-mirai/
371 units in August changed everything. Toyota only need to sell just over 27 cars a month.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

How do we find out who purchased these vehicles?  (Consumer, Business, or Government entities).  I was a bit reluctant to raise my forecast., but data talks and hunches walk.  At this point 113 are left ( making it what, 27 or so per month ).   Originally after the Brexit-hullabaloo, the Yen soared in the currency market (2016 started at 1 usd : 120 jpy; after Brexit 1usd:102jpy )  >> strong yen hurts exports.  It has since settled a bit.

Wow. August. Had to check the Toyota sales sheet.
http://pressroom.toyota.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=5692 to return to later
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/319051
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

This is what I have really been looking for.  It seems only 1000K Miria are forecasted to be sold in the U.S in 2016 and more than a 1000 people want one.  I figure the sales reports on a monthly basis are really based on production capacity.  watch how they are made  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oOUjqxec4bA  http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1100377_more-than-1000-people-want-2016-toyota-mirai-hydrogen-fuel-cell-vehicles
consensus is moving up.  staying ahead a few points
Toyota needs to sell 109 in the next 4 months so 27 per month.

This question is full of uncertainty.  Consensus at 10%.  State/Local government purchases supporting State emissions goals.  Heading into historical seasonal weak car sales period.  Too dangerous to be at 100% but will remain above consensus at 12%.  In reality the 750 will be very very close plus or minus 10?

August, unexpectedly, had  August 371 cars sold. Inexplicable. With 641 cars sold to date, 750 is most certainly in reach. http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html
http://www.toyotanewsroom.com/releases/tms-august-2016-sales-chart.htm
California governments get a deal on Toyota Mirais for fleets
http://www.autoblog.com/2016/06/20/california-government-deal-toyota-mirai-fleet/
Initiating at 70% due to the spate of recent comments.

think I jumped too high.  The funds for the rebate programs are used up, or so it appears.  Perhaps high August sales represent a shifting of purchases to August that would otherwise have occurred later.  But - I really don't know.
Need 109 more sales (or leases) in four months, or at least 27 per month. We should get that, but I will wait until I see the September number before making an extreme forecast.

According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Deal with the state of California vehicles and Toyota sales figures for August 2016.

Entering question just for the points. Wonder why the consensus was so low, with so many clues as to this end of year uptick
http://www.hybridcars.com/california-governments-add-toyota-mirai-fuel-cell-cars-to-their-fleets/
August Toyota Sold 371 Mirai in the US, YTD 641!!! That leaves an average of 28 per month for rest of the year to achieve the 750 target, more than likely event. I was wrong, need to cut my losses
Just released numbers show 671 sold already this year

behind the ball on this.  Unsure if the huge August sales #'s are anomaly, but even if subside back to 40/month, will exceed the target.  And there are *some* vehicles around, though inventory looks lower than it was a couple months ago.

Anyone that has ever worked in Government will tell you that if you don't spend it you will lose it.  Considering the time of year we are in I suspected local/state governments would splurge on a Mirai or some other equipment that is not needed.  I found a nice little blog below talking about special deals for California.  Bottom line is this.  Government money is now spent.  The rest of Mirai sales will require people on a budget.  Considering historical trends and we are heading into a recession I find it hard to believe the Mirai will make it to 750 unless they cut the prices in half.  In which case I'll buy one and forgo my brier score.  But I will bring my forecast up to 10% just in case.  I will evaluate again once 3Q report comes out. http://www.autoblog.com/2016/06/20/california-government-deal-toyota-mirai-fleet/
It the Christmas in September sell a ton

Toyota still has to sell 109 Mirai over the next 4 months for this question to resolve YES. If the 371 sold in August was a purchase by a company or local government, it will not be repeated in following months. They'll probably reach 750 by end of year but not certain.
Following the crowd. I'm glad I raised my forecast (a bit) after seeing the Time ad.

No idea what happened, but unless they are going to be correcting this press release (http://www.toyotanewsroom.com/releases/tms-august-2016-sales-chart.htm) it is a done deal. @dowser in case you haven't seen yet

http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html 270 cars sold in the 7 months to July, and then another 371 in August alone! Just another 80 cars needed in the remaining 4 months - the lowest monthly sale so far this year was 26 back in January.

August sales figures were surprisingly high with 371 cars sold. This brings the total up to 641 units. 
Need to reverse my estimate drastically up
http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html
moving to meet consensus for now, having trouble finding a good, outside view regarding typical timing and efficacy of sales incentives over the course of a year.
Not gonna happen.  Has anyone else noticed that Mirai sounds like the name of some ethnic group from Star Trek?  This is almost surely irrelevant.
Back down 5% on data from @67117mbz below.
http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html based on sales 2016 ytd, unlikely (July_16: 52 / ytd 270)

According to the general news and GJP consensus. 
Less likely with lower gasoline prices.
holding for now, probably time to try to prove myself wrong. starting point may be giving more consideration to end of year incentives.

Going up 10% because I just happened onto a full page Mirai ad in Time magazine. They are offering it on lease for approximately $21k US for three years. This includes fuel for three years. Is this an attempt to get some buzz behind their brand and fuel cells in general? Are they planning to get enough on the road to test a little (bit more)? Is Time (tm) failing and just gave them a good deal on ad space? As other(s) have pointed out, if Toyota can build them, 750 is actually a very small number.

Jan 26; Feb 30; 41 March, 41 April, 40 for May, 40 for June, 52 for July. 270 for year so far. At 50 per month for rest of year comes in at 520. Need 96/mth for rest of year to hit target.
file:///C:/Users/seamus.fagan/Downloads/TMS_July_2016_Sales_Chart.pdf
1% to stop myself being too dogmatic!!!!!!!!!!

270 units so far this year, which makes 750 remote but possible. It is late in the year for Toyota to expand sales outside California, so a new centre of demand to bump the data series appears unlikely. Even so, I can get ~15% chance of hitting 750 using an exponential growth model, but zero chance without assuming it is some sort of exponential process. I'm splitting the difference.
Very, very unlikely. In May I said sales will have to "catch fire." Now they need to explode. If some large corporation orders up 480 for a fleet, I will be proven wrong.
Dropping another 2% on July numbers of 52.

Toyota (TM) is delaying the launch in Japan of its plug-in Prius model by about three months. While declining to give a reason for the delay, the automaker now expects to launch the new model this winter with an initial production reduction.

Down from 10% last month.  http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html 52 cars were sold in July, the highest yet. The total to date for 2016 is now 230. 
An average of 104 cars will have to be sold each month from now on to hit the 750 total for 2016. I don't think this will happen.
July sales of 52 are a 30% increase on the Q2 average of 40 per month.

2016YTD sales are at 270.  The highest month is 52, though it is also the most recent month. Sales/leases would need to average 96 per month for the next five months.  It still seems unlikely, barring a large single order.
Down to 1% on no change in sales over the summer so far. http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html

Too darn ugly. Higher purchase price for competitive set w/o being a premium brand.  Cost of ownership may be high ($75 for a fill up on Hydrogen, not sure on Insurance yet) so I'm thinking we're still looking at early adopters reflected in the sales numbers. Ease of ownership doesn't appear to be great: few ,though growing numbers of hydrogen stations - @Khalid has some more granular data  and interpretation on that. California is the only real U.S. market and the car competes with other EVs for similar incentives.
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/22/automobiles/water-out-the-tailpipe-a-new-class-of-electric-car-gains-traction.html
https://cleanvehiclerebate.org/eng/eligible-vehicles
https://cleanvehiclerebate.org/eng/eligibility-guidelines
http://www.caranddriver.com/toyota/mirai
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/276808 Currently only around 30% of Goal (Khalid breaks it down a bit more in the comment link above) Plus, oil is cheap and Prius sales (very limited comparative case) appear to have fallen in recent years (but admittedly that's just eyeballing the numbers from goodcarbadcar and not fully analyzing the broader EV/FCV competitive set.) Nontheless, I have the feeling I'll be at 0 real quick.
Dropping after June sales. Still strongly suspect that it's a supply issue.  The rest of my previous comment still holds. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/239998

Reducing from 25% last month.
June US sales were 40, same as May and one less than the 41 achieved in March and April. Total this year so far is just 218, which means 532 more are needed in the remaining 6 months if 750 are to be sold. With the best month so far no more than 41, averaging 89 from now on doesn't seem likely. http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html There are still only 27 public hydrogen fueling stations in the US, all in California, just one more than last month, so if lack of infrastructure was holding sales back, it still is. http://www.afdc.energy.gov/locator/stations/results?cng_fill_type=all&cng_psis%5B%5D=all&cng_vehicle_class=all&e85_has_blender_pump=false&ev_connectors%5B%5D=all&ev_levels%5B%5D=1&ev_levels%5B%5D=2&ev_levels%5B%5D=dc_fast&ev_networks%5B%5D=all&fuel=HY&lng_vehicle_class=all&location=California&lpg_secondary=false&owner=all&page=3&payment=all&planned=false&private=false&radius=false&radius_miles=5&utf8=%E2%9C%93 The downloadable spreadsheet from the same site indicates a total of 61 stations open or planned in California, but not enough will be available in the next few months to make a difference. http://developer.nrel.gov/api/alt-fuel-stations/v1.csv?access=all&api_key=FGa7rvCzh6qxJvcov0DrYpIOoGzBP9yGMIxtnQ5i&download=true&fuel_type=HY&status=all Production of Mirais in Japan is around 2000 per annum, with up to 3000 planned for 2017. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Mirai. Almost all of the next few months production would have to be shipped to the US (one car carrier takes thousands of vehicles, so logistics won't be a problem) to get to 750 delivered before the end of 2016. Unless Toyota wants to make some sort of statement, that shouldn't happen, as the Japanese and European markets would suffer. There wouldn't be much point in doing so anyway if sufficient fueling stations aren't ready.
In accordance with Tinned Tuna's calculation of maximum cars possible this year being 613.
Linear model, r=0.69, N=9, (I think this is statistically significant) slope=2.37. Using this indicates that total sales for the year will be ~500. I should do an analysis of the variance on this...

Projecting 33% increase per quarter for a 2016 total of 630. Actual 2016 Q2 in at 40.3 / month only a 25% increase over the 2016 Q1 avg of 32/month. 
Keeping 25% forecast due to the very small numbers involved.
Down 5% since the consensus is dropping.
Dropping again based on latest sales numbers, but will only drop 2%, given that we are talking about so small numbers in absolute terms.
Not with the trend at ~40/mo. and I don't see things catching fire.
Mid year total for 2016 is 218 in total sales/leases.  The goal for 750 would require a jump from the current 40 per month to nearly 90 per month for July-December.
Currently on track for maybe 450.  They will only hit 750 by dint of a wild buying spree where nobody can live without a Mirai.  We are not dealing with Tickle Me Elmo here.
Down 5% to be closer to consensus.
Sales seem to have stabilized at about 40/month. Not sure if this includes leases. So unless sales go up soon, looks like they won't hit target

update: I edited the post to end-note citations/remove them from the body... Sorry/thanks in advance to others who’ve already posted most of this info in other places (edit 2016-06-26: especially @morrell , @Conor , @Khalid , @Raahul_Kumar , @Raisinville , @vii , @mcmahonimal , @PJWenz , @Drew for providing information and/or analysis … sorry for not thanking you specifically when I initially posted, but the method in writing the post was to work from memory and internet-search for cites rather than go through old posts). Below is my attempt to compile in one post what's happened in the Mirai's U.S. launch, as I see it. Maybe I’ll clean up outstanding typos/cites later, maybe not… I welcome others’ reactions, particularly since my forecast is way off consensus. Way back in November 2014, Toyota said it would sell the Mirai in two U.S. markets in 2016: California and the Northeast.[01] Later, on 1 October 2015, Toyota projected an allotment of nearly 1,000 cars to the U.S. in 2016.[02] The Mirai officially went on sale in the U.S. on 21 October 2015 and Toyota then claimed “More than 2,000 people so far have requested to buy a Mirai in California, where it is first available.”[03] By 4 April 2016 it seemed at least possible that Toyota’s partner Air Liquide, would NOT complete hydrogen infrastructure sufficient to fuel the Mirai in the Northeast U.S. until early 2017.[04] Toyota’s undated Mirai FAQ accessed 25 June 2016 says “At this time a vehicle must be garaged and registered within the state of California. Infrastructure is not yet ready to support sales outside of California, but Toyota will continue to support expansion of fueling stations, beginning with the northeast states in 2016. As infrastructure develops further, we will consider other areas.”[05] Despite the 1,900 Mirai demanded (worldwide?) through 1 October 2015 and then-anticipated allotment of ~1,000 Mirai to the U.S., and the more than 2,000 Mirai demanded by people in California by 21 October 2015, the advance-preorder figure for California given around 23 March 2016 was only 300 Mirai vehicles.[06] Perhaps those would-be customers comprising the difference—1,700 Californians who initially wanted the Mirai but were not given an advance preorder—were vetted and deemed poor fits as customers (e.g. because they worked/lived too far from hydrogen infrastructure), or perhaps the 21-Oct. press release was inaccurate. Toyota\nat.mgr.fuelcellvehicles=Ed La Rocque indicated the number of Mirai deliveries in California at the time of his interview had been limited to 100 by the lack of fueling stations rather than demand. (Perhaps oddly, the number from October 2015 through February 2016 (the last full month of sales at the time of the interview) was actually 128… but through January it was approximately 100; see data source on which the forecasting problem relies at [07].) There were 12 fueling stations open in California on 1 March 2016,[08] which was earlier in the month that La Rocque indicated the CA advance-preorder figure was 300.[06] As of 25 June 2016, there are 20 commercial fueling stations open in CA, plus six “non-retail stations” (I assume these are the makeshift stations at dealerships for which “Toyota made the decision to station portable hydrogen fueling trailers at six out of the eight approved Toyota dealerships in California where the Mirai is sold, just so that customers could find a place to refuel”[09]). The projected number of stations before year-end varies from about 38 total commercial stations (and 44 total stations if you include non-retail) at the time of posting according to the organization rolling out the stations[10] or if you prefer Toyota on 1 April, 48 total stations[11], or if you prefer Toyota a few days before 11 April, about 40 stations[12] scheduled to open in CA by the end of the year 2016. Some are currently scheduled to open much earlier than year-end, e.g. August. (For detailed projections on when various CA stations are/will be open according to the organization promoting the hydrogen-fueling-station rollout in California, see the continuously updated table at [10].) Note: Toyota said “…in California… where we introduced Mirai… it would take only about 68 stations to regularly re-fuel about 10-thousand hydrogen fuel cell vehicles.”[11] There were earthquakes in Japan in April 2016 which took down the Mirai production facility for longer than most other Toyota facilities affected by the quakes[13], which may have negatively affected the May numbers (Toyota is known for just-in-time supply chain; see [14]). Then there were explosions on production lines of a brake supplier to the Mirai-producing facility in May, which could further hamper production for the first half of the year.[24] From October 2015 through May 2016, exactly 250 Mirai were sold in the U.S. [07] (presumably all in CA because it is the only place with fueling infrastructure). We therefore assume most of the 300-vehicle advance-preorder demand for the car in California has been met and Toyota will now need sell to other sources of demand to continue the Mirai’s growth. Toyota and Uber (famously headquartered in San Francisco, an early market for the Mirai and other green cars, and the setting of the proverbial South Park episode "Smug Alert!" which features the kids' parents driving a "Toyonda Pious" (which looks like a Prius), and enjoying the smell of their own farts out of wine glasses precipitating an environmental crisis of Smug) announced an MOU in late May 2016 that will mean new financing options for Uber drivers: they can lease Mirai directly from Toyota Financial Services [15] (leases count toward this forecasting problem’s resolution); the money for this appears to come from a $1.6-billion green-financing initiative announced by Toyota a week or two earlier.[16] Toyota only offers the Mirai at eight dealerships in California.[05] Toyota has 1,238 [23] dealerships in California, of which [HOW MANY? ALL?] offer the Prius[CITE]. Toyota's eight Mirai dealerships were selected in part because they sold a high volume of hybrid cars.[17] If Toyota sells as many Prius vehicles in California as it did last year (i.e., ~72,000 [18]; Toyota has already sold ~13,200 through March [19])… so the number of Prius vehicles remaining to be sold this year to hit last year’s target is ~59,000), Toyota would need to sell or lease about 1.1 Mirai for every 100 Prius vehicles sold/(leased?) in California in the back 9 months of the year to positively resolve this forecasting problem. Given Mirai sales through May, each dealership that sells Mirai would need to sell or lease about 10 or 11 Mirai vehicles per month to positively resolve this forecasting problem,[07] if that were the only source of sales (…are there other sources of sales, e.g. do autotrader/dealership cars offered for sale include pre-ordered vehicles? …must a business buy a fleet of Mirai it plans to use as green-cabs through a dealership? I don’t know how it works). There are four dealerships in Northern California and four in Southern California.[05] Toyota told its dealers to hold back deliveries of Mirai until the infrastructure was sufficient to support deliveries so six of eight Mirai dealerships in California were not delivering Mirai as of January 2016. “It’s not a stop-sale,” [Toyota\Lentz] said, keen to reiterate that Toyota hasn’t fully halted sales. “We have just asked [some dealers] not to make deliveries until we have a [nearby] station open.”[20] Given the above factors—apparently there is pent-up demand unable to be satisfied due to inadequacy of hydrogen infrastructure, which is expected to improve throughout 2016, but perhaps not enough to allow enough of a sales push to positively resolve this forecasting problem—I see no reason why Toyota couldn’t more-than-double its Mirai sales in the second half of the year, but also no reason that it’s a sure bet. I expect Toyota is motivated to quickly prove the hydrogen car it named Mirai (Mirai=Future-in-Japanese) is a winner in California in order to out-compete battery-powered electric vehicles (BEVs), which are ahead of hydrogen in California/U.S./earth, but in which Toyota has made little to no investment as far as I can tell, because California is a bellwether for the U.S. clean energy markets and the U.S. is the largest auto market in the world available to a hydrogen vehicle launch. (Presumably it’s too complicated/dicey to try to prove hydrogen infrastructure in China, which is the world’s largest auto market… regulatory permitting and everything else hydrogen infrastructure entails should be significantly complicated in a socialist “state” like California but in a protectionist/communist state like China it is likely even more complicated, particularly for a foreign company headquartered in Japan.) I do not believe anything like manufacturing or shipping enough cars to meet demand could be a problem for Toyota; Toyota is the world’s largest [21] and most admired [22] automaker... making and shipping 751 vehicles is a drop in the bucket for it. I could also see a few northeast sales happening at the tail-end of the year, if infrastructure is rolled out in time. Substantive-edit: I suppose demand itself could theoretically be an issue for Toyota... my sources for Mirai-demand are mostly Toyota, which has incentives to report demand optimistically when trying to generate enthusiasm for a new car as here... but insufficient Californian demand for a thousand or so green-vehicles that are a new technology strikes me as unlikely, particularly given the massive investment in infrastructure Toyota's Mirai is requiring. Dropping 3% based on May sales. The rest of my previous comment still holds. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/239998
Highly unlikely. Monthly sales figures are averaging 35 so far this year, and I don't see any reason for them to pick up anytime soon.
Sales appear to have plateaued at 40 per month so a serious spike would be needed to get to 750-plus for the year.
Too high a proportion of the 2000 total to be produced. I would expect Japan to be the main market for 2016.
Looking at long term interest rates investors expect economies to slow down

I live in the target region in the northeast where Toyota apparently was hoping to sell these cars after their initial introduction in California. I am also the owner of a 2010 Prius, so you would think I would be near the bullseye for the target audience for the Mirai. However, I never heard about the car until reading this question for GJP. If that's the kind of marketing Toyota is doing, they'll never sell or lease more than 750 cars here.

Visited the closest hydrogen fueling station, which happened to be at a busy gas station.  Attendant said that ~10 people per day use it, which seems surprisingly high to me.  Guess I should go find out what other vehicles besides the Mirai - not sure I believe him that some of the cars coming through are Priuses.

Availability of hydrogen fueling stations remains less than anticipated. There are now 26 hydrogen fueling stations open in California, up from 20 last month and 14 the month before.  One would expect to have seen a corresponding increase in sales if lack of stations was the cause, but so that hasn't been the case so far. However, there are another 26 stations listed as planned, of which more than a dozen are shown as opening in May or June (the data can be downloaded from the site below).
http://www.afdc.energy.gov/locator/stations/results?cng_fill_type=all&cng_psis%5B%5D=all&cng_vehicle_class=all&e85_has_blender_pump=false&ev_connectors%5B%5D=all&ev_levels%5B%5D=1&ev_levels%5B%5D=2&ev_levels%5B%5D=dc_fast&ev_networks%5B%5D=all&fuel=HY&lng_vehicle_class=all&location=California&lpg_secondary=false&owner=all&page=3&payment=all&planned=false&private=false&radius=false&radius_miles=5&utf8=%E2%9C%93 Some further info on the Mirai, could be worth following this http://www.edmunds.com/toyota/mirai/2016/long-term-road-test/introduction.html "Configuring a 2016 Toyota Mirai is easy. It's offered in just one trim level, and everything comes standard. Ours carried a sticker price of $58,335. There are incentives, of course. Toyota offers $7,500 in "Trailblazer Purchase Support," the federal government offers an $8,000 tax credit and the state of California offers a $5,000 rebate. All of that adds up to $20,500. Toyota loaned us this Mirai, so we didn't have to do all the paperwork. But that's not all. The Mirai is allowed into carpool lanes, and the first three years of hydrogen fuel are complimentary. The Mirai is starting to look a lot more attractive now, isn't it?
We're fully aware that it's still early days. After all, the number of publicly available stations has only recently crossed into double-digits, and Mirai sales are strictly limited to buyers who live and work in the areas of California those stations serve. But new hydrogen stations are starting to pop up with regularity, and this should quickly expand the car's practicality and radius of operation."

The Case of the Missing Futures Boy howdy this was a rabbit hole. I've concluded that Toyota's production of the Mirai is considerably less than expected. Let me caveat this by saying that finding sales or registration data for Japan was incredibly frustrating. The sales of the top 30 makes are reported monthly [A1] but I could not find Mirai sales reported anywhere, including Toyota's year end financial statements. The data might lie in a book that I can apparently purchase from JADA. I'm going to reach out to a Japanese friend to see if they can get this for me [A2]. Okay let's look at the Mirai in 2015, the first year of its production. On January 22, 2015, Toyota said on its blog "The new plan calls for production to increase from 700 units this year to approximately 2,000 in 2016 and around 3,000 in 2017" [A3].  Where did those 700 Mirai for 2015 go? America received 72 [A4]. The UK got 11 [A5]. Denmark got at least 1 [A6]. After looking at the Toyota site, it seems like every auto show in the world has a Mirai, so let's say there are 10 devoted to promotional things. So that leaves ~600 unaccounted for. Were they all sold to Japan? Not likely. The total estimate for hydrogen cars in Japan as of March 2016 was 400 [A7], another source says 500 as of April 2016 [A8]. Let's add these sales up. From 2015 through April 2016, we can account for (at most) 500 sales in Japan, 210 in the US [A9], and a couple dozen elsewhere (see above). We'd expect around 1250 to have been made during this time period, but we've only found 734. I see two possible explanations for this discrepancy. Option 1: Production is significantly less than expected
To review: we've accounted for 734 Mirai (500 Japan, 210 US, 24 elsewhere). That puts production at approximately 59% of projected (linear regression. y = 85.8x - 120, where x is number of months past 1/1/2015). That might not be ridiculous, considering they were initially hand-assembled by a team of 13 highly skilled workers [A10, A11]. The max output per day is still only 10, so it is reasonable to assume that this is still a highly manual process. Option 2: Toyota is holding inventory (purposefully or lack of demand)
There is a lack of hydrogen fueling stations [A12]. I don't think demand is a problem, given the interest in "reserving" these cars [A13] and a quote from a Toyota executive about wait times [A14]. Would it make sense to hold a bunch of inventory in the US, waiting for the fuel stations to get built? Maybe not, given Japan has 3x the number of stations. Unless Japan is fuel-bound as well, in which case Toyota is holding on to a bunch of cars that everyone wants but no one can fuel. Let's assume we are fuel-bound in the US *and* Japan. Further assume that it's a capacity (rather than location-based) limitation. That implies a limit under 10 cars per station. That just seems way too low. If it isn't, then to sell 750 Mirai this year, California would need to triple the number of hydrogen stations. I think this is unlikely to happen.  Considering these two options, I'd say that this is probably 10% an inventory issue and 90% a production issue. So 734 Mirai + 10% held as inventory account for 800 cars => production is ~35% lower than expected (800/1250).  To summarize so far: through April 2016 we can account for ~800 cars (730 sold, 70 assumed held as inventory). We expected 1250 per Toyota.  Projecting forward, we'd expect an additional 750 cars produced (per Toyota). If the 35% lower production continues, we'll only see an additional .65 * 750 = 487.5 cars produced from now until EOY 2016.  [A1] http://www.jada.or.jp/contents/data/ranking.html
[A2] http://shop.jada.or.jp/i-shop/top.pasp?to=tp
[A3] http://blog.toyota.co.uk/toyota-mirai-production-increased
[A4] http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html
[A5] http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/motor-shows/hydrogen-powered-toyota-mirai-unveiled-ahead-2015-launch
[A6] http://www.carscoops.com/2015/10/denmarks-first-toyota-mirai-gets.html
[A7] http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/03/16/business/japan-eyes-40000-fuel-cell-cars-160-hydrogen-stations-by-2020/#.Vz_U1pMrJ-i
[A8] http://www.greencarcongress.com/2016/04/20160415-meti.html
[A9] http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html
[A10] http://insideevs.com/behind-scenes-toyota-mirai-production-3-made-per-day-videos-images/
[A11] http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/a7ad7876-d0ef-11e5-831d-09f7778e7377.html#axzz49FB8rZu6
[A12] http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1101879_toyota-asks-some-of-cas-8-mirai-dealers-to-hold-off-deliveries
[A13] http://www.carscoops.com/2015/01/toyota-gets-1500-orders-for-mirai-in.html
[A14] http://www.autonews.com/article/20150302/BLOG06/150309994/could-toyota-mirais-hot-demand-and-2-year-backlog-undermine-its
[A15] http://www.autoblog.com/2016/03/18/japan-wants-to-boost-fuel-cell-numbers-100x-by-2020/

A linear regression of the available sales data estimates sales are increasing by ~2.6 vehicles per month, with a standard error of 1.6 vehicles. Even if I assume the true coefficient is one standard error above the estimate and do some rounding up, I get 592 vehicles sold in 2016. The rate could drastically increase, but given the buzz around the Tesla 3, I don't think it's likely.

97 cars sold year to date, with the rollout of hydrogen fuelling stations being the hurdle, its been so slow in fact that Toyota has asked dealers to slow down deliveries (http://wardsauto.com/alternative-evs-hevs-fcvs/lentz-tells-some-dealers-don-t-deliver-mirai-5?page=1). Depending on your source (http://www.marketplace.org/2016/04/11/world/toyota-makes-case-hydrogen-power or http://cafcp.org/) there are around 13-16 fuelling cells in operation in California at this time, with 6 more due to be operational by July, and 40 by year end. Toyota’s initial estimate of sales in 2016 was 1000 units, but they also expected 48 fuelling stations to be operating by end of 2015, and more to be built in 2016
So for California, taking 13 as a baseline supporting 97 sales, and Toyota deliberately trying to slow down sales at that number, and pre-orders willing to be patient in waiting for delivery (sorry can’t find the link for that but it was from an interview with a Toyota executive), it is not clear why it would make strategic sense now to accelerate the roll out in q2, or why customers would push for faster delivery, so if we assume a small increase on March run-rate, and take another 150 sold by July, this would then imply Toyota would have to stick to their run-rate plans of 1000 units per year ie 500 per half (assuming a straight line delivery which admittedly is a stretch) to achieve the goal of 750, but on a lot fewer stations. I would contend that this is unrealistic with a probability of only 18%. Adjusted by:
-	lack of good information to work with +6%, I found very few sources, so hard to make as aggressive a call
-	4 fuel stations in northeast might be worth 50-80 cars this year +8% (http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1103307_sites-of-four-northeast-hydrogen-fueling-stations-announced-by-air-liquide) [I later corrected this "the northeast fuelling stations won't be operational before beginning of 2017 (http://www.automotive-fleet.com/news/story/2016/04/air-liquide-building-hydrogen-stations-in-the-northeast.aspx), so removing the 8% adjustment."]

Per http://www.hybridcars.com/toyota-mirai-goes-on-sale-with-2000-preorders/ Toyota intends to fulfill 1,000 Mirai order through mid 2017.  If that were done at an even pace, it would mean 667 cars in 2016 and 333 in the first half of 2017.  Since they also say they will provide 3,000 cars by the end of 2017, it looks like they are planning to ramp up production in 2017 and build many more in 2017 than in 2016.  This is also consistent with the fact they have only provided 97 cars through the first 3 months of the year.  At an even pace that would be about 400 in 2016.  Sales have increased each month, but the plant closing for the earthquake will temporarily stop that increase. If you assume a one-month interruption in production (for the earthquake) and one month about equal to March production followed by a 20% increase each month, you would have 754 cars.  So 750 isn't out of reach, but it seems a bit too optimistic given their stated goals.
More and more folks are craving for non-fossil fuel cars.
Consumer interest sparked largely by Tesla will carry over to Toyota's entry.
They will sell if the infrastructure is available

Toyota projects the construction of 2000 Mirais in 2016. What's the lag time between construction and transport/delivery? And how badly will the earthquake slow things down? (And how closely will Toyota's production match its estimate?) All in all, I trust Toyota to do something close to what it claims it will do. Going to start above consensus. Note to future self: Scary April/May numbers are going to be expected due to the earthquake, watch June very closely.
Up 10% because I want to be above consensus.

In November 2015, Toyota claimed to have nearly sold out of its 2016 supply with 1900 people wanting a Mirai in the US. (http://www.edmunds.com/car-news/toyota-ramps-up-production-of-2016-toyota-mirai-fuel-cell-to-meet-demand.html) Only problem will be if they cannot deliver 750 this year to the US, as their production of the Mirai was stopped due to the recent earthquake. (http://www.autoblog.com/2016/04/20/toyota-lexus-earthquake-japan-production/) I think current consensus of 25% is way too low, but I'll be conservative and put the number at 50% due to the concerns around production and delivery to the US.
So far, the pace is about 400 for 2016.

Following @Raahul_Kumar It seems like early Tesla sales in California were driven by people with money and an interest in showing they were at the cutting edge. Priuses were so last big thing. I doubt either factor has changed and I would expect Toyota will get the Mirai into as many hands as they can to get real world experience. If I recall correctly, GM built 10k EV1's partly for that reason.
Based on figures so far, 750 seems like an unlikely number

Doesn't look good without new efforts.  Kind of a surprise to me since Prius did so well, but Mirai seems to be a dud so far. A Silicon Valley company might just give up and start again, but Toyota might make a surge so to speak to try to change the current trajectory. Will have to do more searching.
It is difficult to imagine much demand in the short term for a relatively expensive car that is difficult to refuel and has a range of only about 500 km.  I am prepared to be wrong about this.

In 6 months 197 Mirai sold in the US. 
"Toyota Mirai FCV Declared 2016 World Green Car" might impact the sales but "Toyota — and Hyundai, for that matter — can only sell as many hydrogen-fueled cars as the fueling infrastructure can support. To date, Toyota has distributed only 100 of the 300 Mirais preordered in California for precisely that reason. Building out fueling stations is expensive and time-consuming. "
http://www.hybridcars.com/toyota-mirai-fcv-declared-2016-world-green-car/
http://recode.net/2016/03/23/fueling-the-success-of-the-hydrogen-powered-toyota-mirai-is-a-balancing-act/

From the link in "More Info", http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html, Toyota sold or leased a total of 169 Marais in the US between October 2015 and March 2016, with March being the best month at 41 vehicles. They will need to average 65 vehicles per month from now on to hit 750 by the end of December 2016.  The problem they face is a shortage of hydrogen fuel stations. Unlike hybrids which can always go back to regular gasoline, and many all-electrics which can be charged at home, the Mirai needs a complete infrastructure of fueling stations.  Here the signs are not so promising. http://www.autoblog.com/2016/01/23/weak-hydrogen-infrastructure-delays-toyota-mirai-sales/ "Toyota started selling the Mirai stateside in late October 2015, and had hoped to expand sales to the Northeast later this year......The issue is that the California Energy Commission (CEC) slated 50 stations to be operational by the end of last year, but there are only about a dozen open now where drivers of the Mirai and other fuel-cell vehicles can use throughout the Golden State." http://recode.net/2016/03/23/fueling-the-success-of-the-hydrogen-powered-toyota-mirai-is-a-balancing-act/ "To date, Toyota has distributed only 100 of the 300 Mirais preordered in California .... Building out fueling stations is expensive and time-consuming. According to Toyota’s national manager of fuel cell vehicles, Ed La Rocque...., it costs $1 million to set up a single station. In California, after issuing a $7.3 million loan to retail hydrogen-fueling company First Element, Toyota has helped build out 14 stations so far....The next step is building out 12 hydrogen fuel stations in New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island over the next two years....With the expanded infrastructure, Toyota is aiming to sell 3,000 units by the end of 2017." We will have to try and track the numbers of functioning hydrogen fuelling stations in California, and in the next few months in the North Eastern US markets as well. 41 vehicles were sold in March, presumably all within California where there were 14 fuelling stations. To get to an average of 65 per month, there probably  need to be at least 8 more stations functioning in the very near future.  Production of the vehicle doesn't seem to be an issue and there are already more than 750 pre-orders http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1100377_more-than-1000-people-want-2016-toyota-mirai-hydrogen-fuel-cell-vehicles

Absolutely, no doubt about it, the Mirai has exceeded Toyota's sales projections from Day 1. 1.) "Order books for the 2016 Toyota Mirai hydrogen fuel-cell car have been open to California residents since July.
Between then and now, Toyota says customer requests have exceeded the number of cars allotted to the U.S. for the first year of production. Toyota says it has received nearly 1,900 requests for Mirai build slots so far.
However, the company only plans to import 1,000 Mirai sedans to the U.S. for the 2016 model year."
http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1100377_more-than-1000-people-want-2016-toyota-mirai-hydrogen-fuel-cell-vehicles 2.) For instance, they had a team of people predict that the new Toyota Mirai hydrogen fuel cell vehicle would sell well, putting plans in place to make 700 units during the first year of production. However, in Japan alone and in just a couple months, Toyota has already sold over 2,000 units. The Toyota Mirai Has surpassed Sales Projections several times over, and sales haven’t even begun yet in the United States or Europe.
http://www.cavatoyota.com/blog/toyota-mirai-has-surpassed-sales-projections/ I would expect 1 000 sales based on pre orders and car availability.

Rough estimate would indicate a rise to ~80-100 vehicles in December, which would correspond to 600-720 vehicles. All assuming linear growth and neglecting last years data. So starting rather low, however sales could pick up faster which would lead to a revisit of this estimate
